title: po ferries sackings crush tory
story: PO Ferries sackings crush Tory claims that the market is a force for goodTory Chancellor Rishi Sunak claims the markets are a moral force for good. He should tell that to the sacked workers at PO Ferries, writes the Mirrors Jason BeattiePO sacked all  staff via a pre-recorded video message Image: BBC SOUTH EASTopinionByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  Mar |commentsIn a speech last month Rishi Sunak claimed that markets were a moral force for good. He should tell that to the workers at PO Ferries. They will want to know what is moral about bosses sacking hundreds of staff by Zoom with immediate notice, or about the UKaposs feeble employment laws, which allow their jobs to be replaced by cheaper labour. And what is moral about their Dubai-based parent company, DP World, making people redundant despite reaping the benefits of the UK furlough scheme.This is a firm that has spent more than £million sponsoring the European Golf Tour and Renaultaposs F team but claims it canapost afford to offer decent pay and conditions. Its treatment of staff is disgraceful but they operate this way because this Government has given the green light to the worst aspects of capitalism. Tory MPs who yesterday protested against the casual sacking of workers belong to a party that has spent years making it easier for firms to do so.The Government that yesterday complained about the use of fire and rehire is the same one that blocked legislation which would have prevented it. POaposs move is not a one-off example of cut-throat corporate behaviour, it is a harbinger of what is to come as the Conservatives further erode long-standing workersapos rights. They will claim they are cutting red tape to make post-Brexit Britain more efficient but the reality will be more workers escorted from workplaces to make way for cheaper staff. title: priti patel defends refugee checks
story: Priti Patel defends refugee checks because Putin could be sending women with bio-weaponsSpeaking at Conservative Party Spring Conference in Blackpool, the Home Secretary said it was "naive" to believe women could not be "covert operatives". Image: REUTERSByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar Priti Patel has defended stringent checks on Ukrainian refugees because they might be Russian agents bringing biological weapons into the UK.Speaking at Conservative Party Spring Conference in Blackpool, the Home Secretary said it was naive to believe women could not be covert operatives. And she claimed Vladimir Putin could exploit refugee flows to send agents to Britain.In her keynote speech, she said: Iaposve been asked why couldnapost we suspend security checks on people escaping Putinaposs war  Times of conflict, my friends, emphasises our need to remain watchful. I know from the briefings I receive from the intelligence and security services that instability around the world brings with it greater threats. Only four years ago the Russian military intelligence services used a chemical weapon on British soil. She went on: The truth is that a very small number of people can wreak utter havoc. Russia has a history of covert hostile activity.And Iaposm afraid it is naive and misguided to think that only men can be covert operatives, or that refugee flows could not be subject to some form of exploitation.  Ms Patel went on: There are those who would come to our country, to this country, who mean us harm and who plot to strike at our very way of le. The processes that we have put in place closely follow the advice of our intelligence and security services. They mean we can help Ukrainians in need without making our country less safe. It comes as the Home Office said , visas had been granted under the family scheme for Ukrainians fleeing the war by pm on Friday. Ms Patel added: State threats and terrorism take many forms. They also thrive on indference and appeasement and now we are seeing them bolstered by new types of targeted biological, chemical, cyber warfare, ransomware and online threats. Our duty is to safeguard our countryaposs interests and we will never take our eye off the ball when it comes to the safety and security of our country. Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said , places had been created in schools for children fleeing Ukraine and virtual lessons created during the coronavirus pandemic had been translated into Ukrainian. Levelling Up Secretary Michael Gove confirmed more than , households had now offered to house Ukrainian refugees, the majority of whom have made their way to Poland. title: rishi sunak gives insulting two
story: Rishi Sunak gives insulting two minute,  second speech despite cost of living crisisMr Sunak, tipped as a future Prime Minister, made his brief speech via video-link to the conference in Aberdeen. Image: James Maloney Lancs LiveByPaul HutcheonPolitical Editor, Daily Record:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsRishi Sunak has been criticised for making an “insulting” two minute, sixteen second speech to the Scottish Tory party conference.The Chancellor ’s blink and you might miss it address appeared to contain no new content, despite Scots facing falling living standards.Mr Sunak, tipped as a future Prime Minister, made a brief speech by video-link to the conference in Aberdeen. On the pandemic, he said: “Two years ago, we faced the greatest challenge of many of our letimes. “And in response we pulled together our resources as one United Kingdom to get through it, the Daily Record reports.  Mr Sunak added: “Together we protected over one million Scottish jobs, provided loans and grants to almost , Scottish businesses and delivered £. billion in additional funding for Scotland’s public services.” SNP MSP Rona Mackay said: In the middle of a crushing cost of living crisis the man who holds the purse strings thinks itaposs appropriate to devote just two minutes of his time to his own Scottish party conference.In a speech stuffed with shameless self-praise, Sunak provided not a single word of comfort or hope to thousands of hard-pressed Scottish families facing increasing financial uncertainty. This speech was nothing short of insulting and perfectly demonstrates Westminster Tory disdain for the people of Scotland. He also addressed the future: “We must chart a new course together one that delivers greater opportunity in every region and every community. “That is why this UK Government is committed to levelling up, and we are already taking action.“At the Budget, I announced £ million for  Scottish projects from Whithorn to Inverness as part of our Levelling Up and Community Ownership funds.“£ million for the British Business Bank to help small and medium sized Scottish businesses to grow and access to the £. billion Global Britain Investment Fund to secure international investment into Scotland. story: Amazon packer said he was going to work before vanishing without a traceHirsto Angelov, , who lives in Stockport, has not been seen since about pm last Tuesday, and his worried dad has flown to the UK to help find himHirsto Angelov, , suddenly vanished on Tuesday, sparking fears for his safety Image: MEN MediaByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Mar |comments The family of a missing Amazon worker have pleaded with him to get in touch, saying: Please come home, we miss youapos.Hirsto Angelov, , has not been seen since about pm on Tuesday, and his worried dad has flown to the UK to help find him. The Bulgarian-born Amazon packer walked out of the home he shares with his cousin, Vasil Angelov, in Edgeley, Stockport, without saying where he was going. His distraught father, Milen, has flown into Manchester from his home in Varna to try to help find his son.Vasil told the Manchester Evening News that he was becoming increasingly worried for him. Vasil said Hristo took his backpack ashe was going to work and a blanket. But he said he didnapost take the security pass he needs to get into the Amazon hub. He added: Our message to him is: aposWe are all desperately worried about you. Please come home, we miss you. Vasil said Hristoaposs worried mother, Rositsa, is also due to fly into Manchester to help with the search for her son. The cousins have been living at Edgeley since coming to the UK five years ago. Vasil added: We like living in the UK very much. There are many opportunities here. title: brit shoppers face fruit veg
story: Brit shoppers face fruit, veg and cheese shortages after PO ferry cancellationsShoppers have been told the cutting of services by PO may lead to shortages of fresh products like vegetables, fruit and cheese, as well as wineShoppers could face shortages in supermarkets Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Brits could face shortages in supermarkets with vegetables, fruit, cheese and wine among products not arriving after PO suddenly cancelled services.After the firm axed  of its staff fresh fears have emerged that thousands of sheep may also have to be slaughtered. Chaos has hit ports including Hull and Dover after workers who found out they had been sacked on Thursday via a recorded video have begun protests. And passengers left suddenly without transport have been trying to find out information. PO initially said that some services were being cancelled for “several days” but that then reportedly was extended to  days.The supply chain in the UK, already hit by Brexit and Covid, now faces more mayhem with claims that fresh food will not be arriving at shops due to the cancelled ferries. Experts have said that anything from Spanish cheese and wine to French croissants could be affected while farmers have said that livestock including thousands of sheep may have to be slaughtered. Edward Adamson, a sheep farmer from County Antrim in Northern Ireland, said he may have to kill some sheepthe ferry crisis continues.There is no route to the UK mainland for us otherwise. We produce more animals than we need you see and we canapost just keep them, he said, reported The Sun.We just hope it doesnapost last long and will just have to hold on. We can last about three months but then we will have to trade within Northern Ireland and the rest will be slaughtered. [The ferry] is a leline between Northern Ireland and the mainland. When it comes to food itaposs much more important.Director of Food and Sustainability at the British Retail Consortium Andrew Opie told the Daily Mail : Retailers are working with other ferry companies to ensure disruption to PO ferry services do not interfere with the movement of fresh food between GB, NI and EU. Nonetheless, a prolonged interruption to PO services, who are an important part of UK supply chains, could eventually impact the flow of goods. We urge the ferry company and union to find a speedy resolution to the current issues. Protesters in London have called on the Government to nationalise PO Ferries after the company sacked  people without notice. The staff were fired on Thursday and attempts are being made to replace them with agency workers. Demonstrations have been held at ports in Liverpool, Larne, Hull and Dover, as unions call for a boycott of the company.  At least  protesters also gathered outside the officers of PO Ferriesapos owner DP World in Victoria, central London on Friday. Members of the Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers union , Unite, Transport Salaried Staffsapos Associationand Nautilus International joined the demonstration. Protesters chanted: Nationalise PO, Seize the ships, and donapost go PO and Solidarity forever. They also held up signs saying: Save Our Seafarers and Stop the PO jobs carve up. After speaking to the crowd, Steve Hedley, RMT senior associate general secretary, said: It was one of the most brutal and appalling sackings Iaposve witnessed in over  years as a trade unionist. We are absolutely furious.  I meanthis can happen in Dover, this can happen anywhere. If this can happen with PO, every rotten boss and capitalist in the country are going to be queuing up to do the same thing - sack all their staff and bring in staff on half their wages. Mr Hedley said workers were in tears on Thursday as people who had worked there for  years were getting thrown off a ship at two hours notice. These are workers who worked all the way through the pandemic, who were told they were essential workers, heroes, all the rest of it, when it comes down to it, discarded like trash, he added. PO Ferries said in a statement: We took this dficult decision as a last resort and only after full consideration of all other options but, ultimately, we concluded that the business wouldnapost survive without fundamentally changed crewing arrangements, which in turn would inevitably result in redundancies. title: inside uk amish community people
story: Exclusive: Inside UK Amish community where people cope without phones, wi-fi or heatingNew Channel  show The Simpler Le follows strangers who agreed to live on a -acre farmstead in rural Devon with an Amish family of five from Ohio and live by the rules of the Amish communityKevin Gambles in The Simpler LeByChristine Smith:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsSpending a quiet night reading by candlelight and swapping stories around a roaring campfire sounds almost romantic. But whatthat was all you could do because there was no gas, electricity, heating or – shock horror – access to any kind of technology. Would you be able to deal with all of that for six months  Even those who yearn to live a simpler le and escape the stress of the modern world might find it a bit of a stretch. Add in the fact you would have no car and would be running a working farm with ancient equipment and it’s enough to put anyone off.But, tempted by the idea of the experiment for new Channel  show The Simpler Le, people volunteered in their droves. One of them, -year-old mobile phone addict Kevin, said: “I liked the fact we would be living a more simple le and we would put our technology down.” The unemployed waiter, who suffers from colitis, saw the programme as a chance to change.Kevin, who was diagnosed with the condition when he was , explained: “I wanted to adopt a healthier lestyle and this was a chance to do that. “I did rely on my phone. I played video games and I watched too much Netflix… I liked the idea of being closer to nature.” Kevin, from Wigan, Gtr Manchester, was one of  strangers who signed up to live with an Amish family on a -acre farmstead in Devon – and abide by their rules. The traditionalist Christian family, from the American state of Ohio, eschew the trappings of modern le and place importance on self-sufficiency and community instead. And as part of the TV show looking at whether modern le is bad for us, the participants had to be fully self-sustainable and work with others on the farm, as well as help build a barn. They were also given traditional Amish clothes to wear – plain long frocks for the women and simple straight-cut suits for the men, without collars, lapels or pockets. The tasks on the farm were also vied up. Kevin, for example, was put on watering duty, weeding and building the barn. On a typical day, the group would be woken by a loud bell at .am then have porridge with water for breakfast. After, they would head out to the farm with some of the women staying behind to prepare lunch – usually eggs, homemade breador potatoes with some vegetables – and dinner, which consisted of fish caught on the farm lake, with more veg. Kevin thrived on the self-sufficient lestyle. He said: “By the end, I was leading the farm operation and we were selling our vegetables. We learned how to be enterprising, and it was so exciting going to town on a horse and cart.” He told how the evenings were “special” too, without TV or radio. “Once you take away the distractions, there is nothing to do but talk,” Kevin said. “Also, the farm work was so tiring that by pm, you were ready for shut-eye. I read a lot by candle and would normally go to bed around pm.” Kevin made it to the end of the experiment and found it to be a positive experience. But not everyone felt the same. Londoner Penny, who loved the designer lestyle, only lasted a month. The -year-old decided to go on the programme after she was taken to hospital with a terrible bout of Covid alongside her daughter, Dilara, . The former PA to Premier League footballers said: “The idea of escaping from reality seemed liked a good idea.” But Penny admitted that as soon as she arrived with Dilara and her youngest daughter, Azara, nine, she knew she had made a mistake. “To have no phone, TV, electricity, heating or lighting was awful. I struggled so much and it felt so alien.“I was the only one in the main house with children and I would often go to my bedroom and cry.” Four weeks into the experiment, Penny decided to quit. “I missed my fashion, clothes, my family and friends and I was lonely,” she said. But it wasn’t all bad. Penny admitted: “I’ve gone from a size  to a size - and I feel much better.”The Simpler Le starts on Channel  on Tuesday at .pm. They did not deserve to be the pawns in a diplomatic power game between London and Tehran. lt fitted into her favourite cottage, it has been claimed.The Monarch, , plans to spend more time at Craigowan Lodge on her Balmoral Estate, according to reports. Now the cottage at her much-loved retreat in the Scottish Highlands has been fitted with a £, lt. She will also have a new security gate, a state-of-the-art intercom system and a number of news CCTV cameras installed into the property. Palace officials have moved to fit the lt the after speculation the Queen has been struggling with her mobility.She is having dficulty walking her beloved corgis, and needs a walking stick on the occasions she does take them out.The Lton Trio lt is the largest in its range, reports The Sun.“For many years we have thought it would be the perfect place for the Queen to spend more time when she’s older, a source said.Itaposs one of her favourite places in the country. “With the proper lt and now this new security, it can effectively be sealed off so she can spend much more time there quietly in her late nineties.”  Ingrid Seward, editor-in-chief of Majesty Magazine, said she understands why the Queen is keen to spend more time on her Balmoral Estate. “Craigowan is one of the Queenaposs favourite homes, the royal expert said. She loves being there. “The idea of making it easier for her so she can spend more time there in the future is a great idea. “It’s a big, big house. The security makes it very safe. “It makes perfect sense. It’s a home she has always enjoyed and it gives her a bit of independence. The Queen could miss more key events such as Royal Ascot and Garter Day, it has this week been suggested.She pulled out of attending the Commonwealth Day service on Monday, a decision understood to be related to her comfort rather than a specic illness. She now regularly uses a stick and remarked during a recent Windsor audience “Well, as you can see, I can’t move”. Her Majesty has also just recovered from a bout of Covid and spent more than three months resting on doctors’ orders from October and only carrying out light duties after an overnight stay in hospital for tests. Editor of Majesty magazine, Joe Little, has suggested the head of state could be absent from key events in the royal calendar. story: RSPCAs oldest ever cat finds new home at  after huge worldwide responseWhen Morag was given to the animal charitys Worcester and Mid Worcestershire branch by her previous owner, the RSPCA was inundated with adoption offers from all over the worldMorag became the centre of a worldwide response Image: RSPCA MegaByBradley Stokes:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments The oldest cat ever to come into the the RSPCAaposs care has found a new loving home at the age of  - after an appeal went worldwide. After Morag was given to the animal charityaposs Worcester and Mid Worcestershire branch by her previous owner, the RSPCA was inundated with adoption offers from all over the world.An appeal was sent out by staff at the charity and it saw a social media post being shared over , times to help find her special retirement home. Carers of the moggy received offers from Australia, Japan and the USA despite fears her advancing age and slightly scruffy appearance may put adopters off. But now, the cat who the equivalent of  in human years and is believed to be the oldest cat ever to come into the group’s care, has found a new home close to charityaposs branch in Worcester.  Her new owners have said her favourite pastimes are sleeping, mooching about in the garden and upstairs and eating and loves being picked up for a cuddle. Ned Cotton, who manages the rehoming centre, said: “We were absolutely overwhelmed by the response to our appeal for a retirement home for Morag. “Offers of homes came in from Michigan, Florida, Texas and Pennsylvania as well as Australia and Japan. “People also sent in gts and toys and we were so touched with all the messages we received wishing her well. “We never thought for one moment that her story would take off like it did, but a -year-old cat looking for a retirement home to live out the remainder of her days seemed to resonate with people and we were inundated with interest and offers of homes for her.“We’re delighted that she’s found a wonderful home to call her own and we know she’s going to be thoroughly pampered and much loved there, just as she deserves.” The branch has already found homes for seven elderly cats with a combined age of  this year - Violet , Joy , Angel , Holly , Teddyand siblings Barbara and Bernard . title: shocked couple jet2 flight corfu
story: Shocked couple on Jet flight from Corfu are ONLY people on private planeKevin and Samantha McCuillion were flying back to Manchester from Corfu in July  and jested with cabin crew staff that they “needed more leg room”Kevin and Samantha McCuillion Image: Samantha McCuillonByLiv ClarkeGraeme Murray:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA couple were the only passengers on a flight from Corfu and were treated like VIPs. During the three and half hour flight, operated by Jet, Kevin and Samantha McCuillion, felt like they had their own private plane as they ed from the sunshine destination in Greece. The couple were flying back to Manchester in July  and jested with cabin crew staff that they “needed more leg room”.They flew out with Ryanair for a weekaposs holiday in Corfu and wanted to extend their stay and booked new flights home with Jet.After arriving at the the airport on the Saturday night they realised no other passengers were around.Sam, , told the Manchester Evening News: “It was unbelievable, obviously Covid was still a thing at the time.I never thought I would travel alone in a plane.When we went to check in for the flight we thought it was a bit odd that nobody was around, there still weren’t any other passengers at passport control and I started to get a bit panicky. “I wonderedsomething was wrong and our flight had been cancelled or we were late, the airport was so quiet but the staff assured us everything was ok.It was getting later and later and past the departure time. Then the shuttle bus arrived to take us to the plane and we were the only ones on board - we thought we were just late for the flight. “Then we got to the plane and went up the steps, the captain was there with two flight attendants and they told us we were the only ones going on the plane.  The captain said he would tell us all the information, where we flying over and things like that, at the front of the plane instead of making an announcement. “He then said once we’d taken off we can do whatever we like and treat the plane as our own private jet - he said we could run up and down the aisle and do what we wanted. The crew told the couple that since they had toto Manchester anyway, they decided not to cancel the flight, in spite of the lack of demand.Sam, who works as a clerk for the NHS, added: “It was amazing, the staff were lovely, they gave us champagne to drink, sweets to eat, we didn’t have to pay for anything.We didn’t actually run up and down but we laughed and joked with the attendants, we kept saying that we needed more leg room. We still had to wear masks though.“It was such an incredible experience and I don’t think it would happen again, it’s like winning the lottery. It was actually quite bizarre, at one point I dozed off and when I woke up I wondered where everyone was. “When we arrived at Manchester the airport was empty too, it was around am. We got to passport control and the guy from border force looked at us and askedthere was anyone . “We told him what happened and he couldn’t believe it, he said that would never happen to him.I think it was a Covid thing, my friend had recently flown to Portugal and there were only ten people on her flight and I thought that was unbelievable - then we ended up with a whole plane to ourselves. “We had originally flown with Ryanair, but we paid an extra £ for the tickets with Jet  when we extended the stay - £ for a  seater plane all to ourselves.We’re going back again this summer and it’s a place we’ve been to many times, I can’t wait to show them all what happened.” A spokesman from Jet said: “We are delighted that Kevin and Samantha got to experience our VIP customer service in true style.Due to the traffic light system in place for international travel at the time, customers had only just been able to start travelling to Corfu again, meaning flights departing from Manchester were very busy but flights back were much quieter.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Private jetsJetOn Instagram" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: sleep symptoms see your gp
story: Sleep symptoms to see your GP about immediately - including sign on your legsAs part of World Sleep Day, GPs share the signs and symptoms to look out to knowyou are too tired and should seek advice from a doctor to ward off serious health conditionsIf you struggle to sleep it might be time to seek help Image: Getty ImagesByAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsGetting a good night’s sleep is essential for our health as our bodies take care of essentials such as healing our hearts and blood vessels. We all feel tired occasionally but ongoing issues with getting some shuteye can cause an increased risk of heart and kidney disease, high blood pressure and strokes. So how do you know when it’s appropriate, and necessary, to see a doctor about fatigue or other sleep related issues  Itaposs World Sleep Day, anditaposs been a while since you got a restful night because of your sleep habits, it might be time to seek medical help, says the Daily Record.Here, GPs share five signs and five symptoms to never ignore. Heavy snoringIt might seem harmless but heavy snoring might be a sign of sleep apnoea.“This is an often-missed cause of poor sleep, responsible for chronic tiredness during the day, and even road traffic accidentssufferers fall asleep at the wheel,” says GP Dr Claire Morrison, a medical advisor for MedExpress . “It’s caused by the throat repeatedly closing off during sleep, making oxygen levels fall, and resulting in frequent waking. It’s most common in those who are overweight and who have a thick neck.”  Other signs include waking with a dry mouth and or headache, and feeling very tired and irritable during the day, she says.Or your partner might notice long pauses between breaths when you’re asleep, and then a gasping or choking sound when breathing resumes. While mild cases don’t always need to be treated, in extreme cases sleep apnoea can be dangerous – the NHS notes a higher chance of having a stroke and a serious accident caused by tiredness.Extreme tiredness all the time It could be a sign of anaemia, says Dr Ross Perry, a GP and medical director of Cosmedics . “Other symptoms [of anaemia] include a lack of energy, pale looking skin, headache, dizziness, light headedness, cold hands and feet and brittle nails.” Extreme tiredness can also be a key sign of undiagnosed or insufficiently treated thyroid disease, he adds. The condition occurs as a result of a decrease in thyroid hormone production. “You may sleep more than usual but still feel completely exhausted. At times, you may fall asleep during the day or very quickly at night. In the morning, you may find it dficult to get out of bed.  “Extreme tiredness [also] could be a symptom of coeliac disease, and for some, it may be the only symptom,” says Perry. “The gut damage caused by coeliac disease results in poorer absorption of essential food nutrients involved in energy metabolism, including iron, folic acid and vitamin B.” Restless legs This is a nervous system condition associated with an uncomfortable “tingling or fizzing sensation” in the legs, eased only by moving the legs constantly, says Morrison. “It tends to be worse in the evenings and at night, sometimes making it impossible to sleep properly. It can affect the arms too.”It’s thought to be caused by a lack of the dopamine chemical in the brain, she explains, and it can be triggered by a number of underlying causes – so it’s important to work out what. It may be come about during pregnancy or happen without any obvious reason at any age, though women are twice as likely as men to develop it and it’s also more common in middle age. However, restless legs may also be triggered by “iron deficiency, kidney impairment, diabetes, under-active thyroid, fibromyalgia or Parkinson’s disease”.“Drugs which aggravate the condition include anti-histamines, anti-sickness medication, and anti-depressants, so do tell your doctor about your symptoms before being prescribed anything,” Morrison says. A complete loss of interest in sex “[For men] testosterone deficiency is another common problem associated with tiredness and one of the trademark symptoms of low testosterone in men is chronic fatigue – the type of tiredness that doesn’t improve after rest,” explains Perry.  It can be part of the normal ageing process – testosterone levels are likely to decrease in all men with age , so interest in sex may decline slightly too. “However, it’s not normal for testosterone levels to get so low that fatigue impacts daily activities or for there to be a complete loss of interest in sex, so do visit your GP,” he adds. Mental health concerns affecting sleep It goes without saying that it’s worth chatting to your GPyou’re struggling, but many mental health conditions can cause dficulty sleeping, so it’s not uncommon for issues to come to light at night. “There is a close link between sleep and mental health, and poor sleep can aggravate mental illness, so it’s very important to address sleep problems early on,” says Morrison. “Mental health problems that commonly affect sleep include depression, anxiety, stress, panic disorder, post traumatic stress disorder, and obsessive compulsive disorder, for example.” Signs of mental illness include low mood, excessive worrying, tearfulness, irritability, low self esteem, lack of motivation, inability to concentrate, intrusive thoughts, loss of pleasure in le, poor appetite, and or binge-eating, she adds. “You may benefit from talking therapy such as ‘cognitive behavioural therapy’, and or medication, but make sure your doctor knows about the insomnia, as some anti-depressants can help promote sleep, whereas others may make it worse and are best avoidedpossible.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSInsomniaPrescriptionsSleep" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Stunned residents must pay £, a year for park they never knew was being builtA letter was sent to every property on The Mill estate which is home to around  flats and houses claiming each address will not be paying more than  th of the cost of the parkThe Mill estate, Cardf where the park was built Image: Media WalesByFfion LewisGraeme Murray:,  Mar |commentsStunned residents have been told they must pay £, a year to maintain a park they never knew was being built. Households in Canton, Cardf received a letter this week requesting a £ annual service fee to maintain Riverside Park. The letter was sent to every property on The Mill estate which is home to around  flats and houses.It claims that each address will not be paying more than  th of the cost of the park, reports WalesOnline. Andthere there were  payments of £, this would equate to £,. The park, which opened in July , consists of a simple wooden climbing frame, a picnic table, a bench and two bins.  Residents at The Mill entered into a service charge agreement for maintenance of the estate when they completed on their purchase. But many property owners said they were not consulted about the addition of the park, nor the service cost that would come with it. A letter sent to residents at the time reads: The service charge year shall run for a period of  months from  April in every year. We are notying you of the estimated Service Charge, which is £.for the period covering  April  to  March  in relation to your property. Please note that this is an estimate only of the service charge payable this service charge year.  Ben Jordan owns his property in The Mill and has lived there for over two years. And that letter has gone to every property, which is  properties, so thataposs £, a year to maintain one wooden frame. Fellow householder Josh Jenkins said: I knew that there was a park there, but in terms of it being our responsibility to fund or look after it, this is the first I have heard of it. When we were going through the process of moving in, we were told there would be a service charge but we were told it would be going specically to a company called aposGround Solutionsapos and they would be doing the grounds maintenance of the entire estate. story: UK shops across the country will have NO free-range eggs from MondayChickens have not be been allowed outdoors since November over fears of avian flu outbreaks which means their eggs cannot be labelled as free-rangeEggs will not be allowed to be labelled free-range from Monday Image: Getty ImagesByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsConsumers will no longer be able to buy free-range eggs in the UK from Monday. The birds have not be been allowed outdoors since November over fears of avian flu outbreaks.Any eggs that will be sold in shops will have to have a sticker or label on it saying they are barn eggs - which is to explain they have been produced by hens housed indoors. There were more than  reported outbreaks of avian flu this winter in England as officials said it was the largest-ever outbreak of avian flu”. The UK government had ordered that birds reared for meat and eggs need to be kept indoors since November to reduce the risk of outbreaks.  This means that because they have been indoors for so long the birdsapos eggs can no longer be labelled free-range. This rule applies to all birds. Farmers were hoping the government were going to lt the housing order next week but after more avian flu outbreaks it is remaining in place. Suffolk-based egg producer Daniel Brown, who has more than , free-range hens, says they are coping well indoors. He told the: We’ve given them extra things in the shed-like hay and grit to give them things to peck at and keep them amused.”“A chicken won’t be bothered about not going outside in December and January, but when it’s nice in May they’ll want to be out late into the evening.He says he hopes the order is lted once the weather starts to warm up.for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email .Avian flu outbreaks have spread across Europe overwinter as France is trialling a potential vaccine. However, it has proven tricky because of the numerous strains. Some countries have banned importing poultry meat from countries that vaccinate birds. A spokesperson for the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs said: “The -week grace period we allowed for free-range eggs has now been exceeded, and eggs must now be marketed as ‘barn eggs’. We have worked closely with the sector and retailers to implement these changes as smoothly as possible.”  The British Retail Consortium said supermarkets would be providing signage to explain the change to consumers, but “when the current measures are lted, eggs will go back to being free-range”. Aimee Mahony, the National Farmers’ Union’s chief poultry adviser, said: “Shoppers may notice dferent labels on egg packs explaining the eggs have been laid by hens temporarily housed to protect their health and welfare. “Once the risk levels have reduced and the housing measures have been lted by Defra, birds will be able to go outside again.” The Mirror contacted Defra for a comment. story: UK weather forecast: C scorcher today as country set for long run of dry weatherBrits are set for a C scorcher today making it the hottest day of the year, with a high pressure system bringing blue skies and sunshine up and down the countryTemperatures could hit C today Image: Getty ImagesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Brits can look forward to an “extended run of dry weather with lots of sunshine” with temperatures hitting C on Saturday making it the hottest day of the year.People are set to head to the beaches with sunshine “up and down the country” and temperatures will build on Friday’s peak, the warmest day so far, and hit C. BBC weather forecaster Chris Fawkes said: “Our settled weather is due to this big area of high pressure.“We do have a weather front coming in on Sunday and Monday, very weak affair, could bring an odd shower but the emphasis nevertheless remains on an extended run of dry weather with lots of sunshine in the forecast as well. It is going to be mild for the time of year.” BBC weather colleague Helen Willetts said that there may be some frost first thing in the morning on Saturday but after that it will feel “really quite warm”.  “.C in West Sussex it was the warmest day of the year so far , no surprise really because the March sunshine is strengthening and there was barely [any] cloud to block that sunshine out during the course of Friday and it will be a similar story through the day ahead,” said Ms Willets. “But a chilly start on Saturday and some patchy fog around. So the frost is more likely across northern and eastern areas not as widespread as Friday morning and there will still be some pockets around.” There will be be a breeze about on Saturday, especially on the eastern side of the country, but it will be a day to be outdoors and enjoy the sun.  Met Office forecaster Alex Deakin “A cracking day on Saturdayyou like sunny skies, there are plenty of blue skies up and down the land thanks to high pressure.”He said that the hottest temperatures are set to be in Scotland where it could hit C. “Temperatures will be well above average inland in the sunshine ... C, C maybe in Cardf and Glasgow, said Mr Deakin.  That breeze though will be more noticeable on the east coast, even here the temperatures are above average but feeling a little fresher C or C compared to Friday’s values. The top temperature actually likely to be across the Highlands of Scotland where we could easily get to C or possibly squeak up to C for the first time this year.” UK forecast for the next  days Fine, dry and mostly sunny today, but also windy. Today: Fine, dry and bright with plenty of sunshine. Windy though, especially in the south and west. Feeling pleasantly warm in the sunshine and out of the wind in many areas, though perhaps quite chilly in some North Sea coastal areas. Tonight: Turning chilly this evening and then dry but quite windy with mostly clear skies overnight. Colder than last night with a touch of frost in some rural and upland areas. Sunday: Most parts dry with good spells of sunshine. Cloudier at times over East Anglia and far southeast England where a little showery rain is possible. Breezy and colder than today. Outlook for Monday to Wednesday: Chance of early showers in the east on Monday. Otherwise, widely fine and dry with plenty of sunshine for most. A cold start for most on Monday before turning warmer. However, the mist has cleared, making way for a bright, bright day for many across the UK today. Temperatures are expected to peak at C today in Edinburgh, C in Cardf and C in Liverpool. And Londoner are in for an unseasonably warm afternoon, with the mercury expected to rise up to C.Through the day on Friday, lots of blue sky and plenty of sunshine,” Met Office meteorologist Claire Nasir said.Ms Nasir said conditions may get a little hazy towards the west of Scotland as more high cloud was seen there and a breeze developed across the Western Isles. However, it was expected to remain warm and dry throughout much of the day. story: I fell pregnant at  and didnt tell my dad - he had to deliver my baby at amMum-of-two Elle Woods has revealed how she found out she was seven months pregnant when she was  - and then she gave birth in the middle of the night with her dadHer dad delivered the baby  minutes after learning she was pregnant Image: therealelwoods TiktokByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Mar |comments As a woman, hereaposs probably nothing more terrying than the prospect of discovering youaposre expecting a baby really late into the pregnancy - but to go through all of that at the age of  is just a whole dferent ball game.Thataposs exactly what happened to mum-of-two Elle Woods, who discovered she was seven months pregnant with her daughter during a routine trip to see her nutritionist. The then-teen was so terried she didnapost tell anyone, until she woke up in agonising pain at am one morning and was forced to tell her dad - who delivered the baby  minutes later.In a series of clips on TikTok, posted from her handle @therealelwoods, Elle told her followers: I found out through my nutritionist - not my GP - and I just didnapost tell anyone I was pregnant.Just a few weeks later, the teen woke up in the early hours in a lot of pain and asked her dad to get her some painkillers - but she quickly realised she was already in labour, and all of a sudden half of the babyaposs head [was] already out. Rising to the occasion, Elleaposs shocked dad quickly phoned emergency services, but with the nearest hospital a -minute drive away, operators told him heaposd have to deliver the baby himself. [He] moved me to the en-suite as that was the largest tiled area and they put down a whole heap of towels, she explained in a follow up clip. My uncle - my dadaposs brother - was living with us and he was in charge of keeping my sister with Downaposs Syndrome occupied with other things so she didnapost know what was going on. Dad said it was quite quick. Iaposve had a second child since and I laboured really quick with him as well. Elle continued: When the ambulance came [ minutes later], they packed me up and took me to hospital. I donapost remember a lot because I did go into shock and I lost a whole lot of blood. Fortunately, both Elle and her daughter - who is now  years old - were both fine, and the girlaposs grandfather decided he would become a full-time granddad so his daughter could go back to school while he took care of the baby. Elleaposs daughter - Belle - is now the best of friends with her granddad, and she has since welcomed a second child with her husband.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: my neighbours never clean up
story: My neighbours never clean up after themselves - theyre angry I reported themA woman was left frustrated at her new neighbours after they kept leaving their kids toys outside their housing compound - so she reported them to their landlordThe woman is frustrated with her messy neighboursImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Mar |commentsItaposs not uncommon to find yourself clashing with your neighbours over things like noise complaints and where you put your wheelie bin, but most of us will be as cordial as we can to those living beside us - evenwe donapost get along.But one woman on Reddit has found herself at loggerheads with her new neighbours after they consistently failed to clean up after their children and created a mess of bikes, scooters, and balls lying in the middle of the road. The woman, who posted her story anonymously, explained she lives in a housing compound made up of  families, and while most of her neighbours are very polite, the new arrivals have been disrupting the balance.She said: I live in a compound with  houses altogether. Four weeks ago a new family moved into the only remaining empty unit. They have  small children a boy around  and a girl around . Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. All the kids that already lived here play on the main road that runs through the compound as it is private access only and therefore relatively safe. But they always make sure to stay away from driveways and not hit anyone’s car with their football tennis ball shuttlecock etc. It’s nice seeing the kids play together after school and they are all very polite and move out of the waysomeone is driving through the street. However, this new family leaves their toys including scooters and bikes and even a cricket bat lying in the middle of the road. The kids also throw their balls into garages. The mum even claims the children have thrown bits of pebble at her windows at night and woke up her two-month-old baby in the process. She initially confronted the parents about their kidsapos behaviour but nothing has changed - so sheaposs now reported them to their landlord along with video proof.  She added: They have snuck up my driveway right next to my windows and thrown bits of pebble at the window and then screamed when my husband went to check what was going on, which woke up my  month old newborn. After  weeks of this, I went to the new neighbours and asked them to keep their kids under control. The we told me their nanny cleans up after the kids , so there is no problem. I got frustrated and started taking photos every time the new kids left a mess and blocked the road. I sent that, along with a video of them sneaking into my garage and driveway, to the landlord who said he would take care of it. Since sending the proof to the landlord, the neighbours have been better behaved - but are furious that an anonymous person reported them. The woman said: I noticed that they have been better behaved this week and casually brought it up with my other neighbour, who said that the new neighbours had received a warning from the landlord and were angry that someone had reported them. Now I am wonderingI should have tried to talk to them again instead of just straight away reporting them. story: Woman creeped out by giant statue that looks like Nicolas Cage in empty house for saleJess Hogan was creeped out when she saw the giant statue inside an otherwise empty property that was up for sale - as it bore a striking resemblance to Nicolas CageThe house was empty and looked innocent from the outside Image: Kennedy News LeaderfoxByZahna EklundAudience writerRebecca Cooley:,  Mar |commentsA house-hunter was left feeling as though she was in a horror film after stumbling across a giant statue of a religious figure inside an otherwise empty property.Jess Hogan was looking at houses online when she spotted the bizarre find lurking in the corner of one of the rooms in the four-bed house in Poole, Dorset, and couldnapost help but notice the striking resemblance between the statue and acting icon Nicolas Cage.The le-size wooden statue actually depicts Saint Francis of Assisi wearing flowing robes and holding a cross, but Jess couldnapost help but draw comparisons between the creepy statue and the National Treasure star. The -year-old, who is from Poole, made the discovery after initially being impressed with pictures of the £, property and wanting to see more in a virtual tour. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. When she opened up the tour option, the psychology student was shocked to find the ft unexpected house guest lurking in the otherwise empty living room. She said: I was looking at houses in that area and saw that one and had a look through the pictures. It looked alright and I saw it had a virtual tour so I used that to have a better look around. It was a bit of a shock going in and seeing a weird religious statue in one of the rooms - I just thought it was really funny. Because I was doing the virtual tour it was literally like walking into the room and there was just this thing in the corner. It kind of felt like the start of a horror movie - itaposs like a warning sign that the house is haunted or that something bad happened there. Itaposs almost like itaposs the statueaposs house and he has to stay there - maybeyou move him something bad will happen. It probably comes to le at night.  After virtually coming face-to-face with the bizarre figure, the student tweeted about her discovery and said she felt unsettled by the religious statue. She wrote: So I was doing a virtual house tour on Rightmove and I aposwalkedapos into one room and was greeted by this thing. Holy s**t. Commenters shared in Jessapos horror as they said they were convinced the statue was haunted. And one even drew the comparisons to Nicolas Cage, writing: Is that Nic Cage   The seller of the property has insisted the statue isnapost haunted and has actually had a positive impact on their lives since they picked it up in Bali, Indonesia - evendoes sometimes scare their house guests. They said: Itaposs a carving of St Francis - the patron saint of children and animals. We found it in Bali when buying furniture for our reclaimed furniture shop and shipped it back - it was so unusual compared to all the other Indonesian carvings. It had a time at our old house and then a time at a church in Bournemouth. We are now undecided on what to do with it so it ended up in the house. It will be the last thing we move as it weighs about kg. We bought it and it took us on a very positive journey afterwards so definitely more of a good thing in our lives. We’re now in a free-for-all. Fingers crossed, because it’s a gamble with the nation’s health and the lives of the vulnerable. No mandatory masks on planes, trains and buses, or in schools or shops. That sounds correct, but the abolition of official rules brings confusion and uncertainty. In this do-it-yourself pandemic policy, who knows how to behave Boris Johnson, who uses the Ukraine war as a covering for his face , wants us to believe it’s all over. It isn’t. Driven by the super-infectious Omicron BA iant, new cases are up by %. There are , in hospital, with  on ventilators. Deaths on Wednesday numbered , bringing the seven-day total to . Protection gained by booster jabs is fast disappearing, and we’re still waiting for the vital fourth dose. It may come soon for the over s and vulnerable, but not until later in the year for the general population. With a hundred deaths being recorded every day, this feels like Covid complacency.And the Government is dragging its feet over the independent pandemic inquiry. It’s unlikely to take evidence before the winter – and not report until at least two years.This deliberate delay takes the verdict on the Great Tory Pandemic Bungle until well after the general election, thereby letting Boris Johnson off the hook. I don’t know about Covid being endemic, but we are being asked to live with endemic political corruption. *********** In , King James I described smoking tobacco as loathsome to the eye, hateful to the nose, harmful to the brain and dangerous to the lungs. And he likened the “black, stinking fume thereof” to the Stygian smoke in the bottomless pit of hell. I don’t know how he knew that because nobody who’s been there has ed to tell the tale. No matter. His diagnosis is correct. In , , people in England died from conditions related to the lethal ciggy. With addiction rates among - year olds up by %, anti-smoking tsar Javed Khan urges the Government to raise the age for buying fags to “, ,  or even ”. My father, a heavy smoker, died at . I’d raise the age to ... with written permission from both grandparents. *********** Anti-Ukraine war protesters who broke into the Belgravia mansion of sanctioned Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska found it empty.I half expected them to find Milord Peter Mandelson lolling in an armchair sipping a glass of hot water, his favourite tipple.He knew Deripaska “not very well” but well enough to be entertained on the yacht of Putin’s admirer in Corfu, where he joined a yoga session with his host. Pally Peter, in those days a Brussels bureaucrat, flattered oily Oleg as “not only wealthy but well-read, and voraciously interested in a constellation of social and economic ideas, as well as Russia’s future.” I’ll say. We haven’t heard much from Mandy about his wealthy Russian pals lately. I wonder why  *********** Early man’s greatest invention was the handle, which made stone tools more efficient for bashing, chopping and scraping, according to Liverpool University researchers. Sorry, Scouse pointy-heads. That honour belongs to the bed. story: Woman drives for four days with  dogs crammed in car to flee UkraineOwner Olena Lukash is ing to Ukraine to save more animals in danger - but the -year-old needs money for food, medicine and fuel to continue her rescue missionOwner Olena Lukash with her French bulldogs Image: Kennedy News and MediaBySophie NorrisPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |comments A brave dog owner crammed her  French bulldogs into a car and drove through Ukraine as Russian bombs fell overhead - and sheaposs preparing toto the warzone to save more aposdefenceless animalsapos. Olena Lukash initially aposdidnapost believe a war could startapos in her home country until Russian shells began to land near her house, just outside of Kyiv.However the -year-old soon realised she would have to save herfour-legged childrenfrom the terrying threat as she decided to flee her home and head for Poland.Photos show  of the dogs squeezed into the kennel owneraposs Hyundai Tucson for the four-day drive - the poor pooches blissfully unaware of the terror they were escaping. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. Remarkably, after Olena and her husband Alexander left the dogs in Poland they then ed to their Russian-occupied town to rescue  more and then fled to Vinnitsa,  miles away from Kyiv.Next week, the breeder will face the same gruelling drive back to Poland, but Olena admits money is running out fast as they face a £ [₴,] bill each week just to feed the dogs.Olena, from Kyiv, Ukraine, said: My dogs are my children. My job is my dogs. These are all French Bulldogs - my favourite breed for  years now.I didnapost believe a war could start. The first week I thought that everything would end quickly, then shells began to fall near the house and I realised that I needed to save my four-legged children.I took the first batch of dogs,  dogs and  puppies, to Poland on March . The drive took me four days. There is a lot of traffic on the roads. I ed home when our village was occupied by Russian troops and took out the rest of the dogs and puppies,  dogs and  puppies.Now we are km away from the hostilities but I plan to take all my dogs to a safe place in Europe.I love my dogs very much. I am ready to do a lot to save the lives of defenceless animals. I have strength and doing for this.They are obedient and I am strong. I manage. Most importantly, we are all together and safe.Olena is now in Vinnitsa in central Ukraine with the remaining dogs but claims they need money for food, medicine and fuel to continue their rescue mission.Olena said: I am with dogs in Ukraine, the city of Vinnitsa, with my friend. We need funds for food, medicine for dogs and fuel for the car to continue on our way.Thousands of people write to me. I donapost even have time to read everything.I try to let people know that I need help. Inidual people help financially, the rest sympathise.All American friends are generally silent - they do not want to help.So far I have ed to Ukraine once. I need to do two or three more trips. I have never counted how much I spend on dogs, but I think that [£] a week would be enough for me to feed them all.It is impossible to count on medicines and assistance because this all happened spontaneously. Gasoline is very expensive now.I need to raise money for the long haul and find families for my puppies.The married animal lover claims she will continue to rescue other dogs as soon as she gets her to safety, even forming groups across neighbouring countries to ensure rescued dogs find a safe long-term home.Olena said: First I have to provide a safe place for my dogs in Europe then I will help other dogs from Ukraine.We have already created groups and selected people to deliver animals from Poland and Romania throughout Europe, but they also need financial assistance for fuel.It is a lot of work and I have very little energy now. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: yvie burnett on contrasting performances at the baftas
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowInveraray History Society took a walk on the wild side at its latest meeting as Argyll Estates# head stalker set his sights on an entertaining evening.Tom Kirsop provided society members with an informative and imaginative talk at their February gathering, covering his work and experiences on the local estate.Growing up in Clydebank, Tom had always had an interest in animals and moved to Argyll as a forest ranger in Dalmally.Since starting to work with Argyll Estates, which he thoroughly enjoys, Tom has been able to develop his work with animals in many dferent ways.In Queen Victoria’s time the current ,-acre estate was on an even bigger scale and has witnessed a huge increase in the number of deer since then.This has been due to the lack of any natural predators and, with further planting of trees since the s, the deer have had more protective covering.Modern inventions such as drones and the use of argocats, have made it easier for people working on estates to estimate numbers of deer more accurately and to be able to meet the necessary annual targets of keeping the deer population to manageable levels.Working on the estate also involves a range of other projects, such as collecting data on golden eagles, barn owls, making fishing available at the Glen Shira dam and taking clients out stalking.More recently Tom has started up West Highland Wildle Tours to give people of all ages a real insight into the wildle and beautul scenery on our doorstep.For the society#s March meeting, Ken MacTaggart will give a presentation about #The Medieval Pilgrim Way to Loch Awe#.The venue will be Inveraray church hall on Tuesday March , starting at .pm.Everyone is welcome. Please follow the Inveraray and District History Society on Facebook for our latest news.

title: science matters another unwelcome invader 2
story: Dorothy H CrawfordUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowMost of us are active by day and rest by night, but within these confines there are several possibilities ranging from larksto owls .These preferences, called chronotypes, have a genetic basis that controls one#s biological clock, but this can be modied by ious factors such as light exposure, age and lestyle.However, when the genetic and environmental cues are not aligned a chronic condition known as #social jetlag# may ensue.This problem is exacerbated during adolescence when chronotypes become increasingly delayed, but schools start early in the morning.This can cause sleep loss that may lead to major health and psychological problems and also affect academic performance.In a recent study scientists examined how the interaction between chronotype and school start time influenced inidual academic performance* by taking advantage of a high school system where  students had been randomly assigned to lessons in the morning , afternoonor evening .This enabled the unbiased testing of the effect of chronology and school schedules on academic performance in adolescents aged - years and - years.The results showed that among the early morning group, very few students got adequate sleep.The larksoutperformed owlsin all school subjects and this effect, which increased as students progressed through the school, was most extreme in maths.This outcome, however, was not evident in those having afternoon schooling, and the situation almost reversed in those receiving evening schooling, where students with later chronotypes performed slightly better in languages than the early chronotypes in the same group.Clearly academic performance is influenced by biological iation in daily rhythms, to an extent that has previously been underestimated.The study authors, while conceding that it is impractical to attempt to fully align school timetables to inidual chronotypes, suggest that it may be possible to, for example, progressively delay school start times during adolescence.* Goldin et al.  https:doi.org . s---.
